content.description: A 99 percent confidence interval for a difference in means was given as <math alttext="25.1 plus or minus 4.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.1</mn><mo>Â±</mo><mn>4.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: Assuming all conditions for inference were met, which of the following is a correct interpretation of the 99 percent confidence level?

choices.label: In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the intervals constructed from the samples will extend from 20.8 to 29.4.
In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the sample means will fall between 20.8 and 29.4.
In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the samples will fall between 20.8 and 29.4.
In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the intervals constructed from the samples will capture the difference in sample means.
In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the intervals constructed from the samples will capture the difference in population means.

content.answer: In repeated samples of the same size, approximately 99 percent of the intervals constructed from the samples will capture the difference in population means.

topic.text: 7.7: Justifying a Claim About the Difference of Two Means Based on a Confidence Interval

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
